moxie

Interface ObjectExpectation<T>

  • Type Parameters:
    T - Type of the mock object for which expectations are being set.
    All Superinterfaces:
    Cardinality<ObjectExpectation<T>>, Expectation<ObjectExpectation<T>,Object>

    public interface ObjectExpectation<T>
extends Expectation<ObjectExpectation<T>,Object>, Cardinality<ObjectExpectation<T>>
    Interface containing domain-specific language methods called in "the middle bit" of statements that set expectations on mock object instances.

    See documentation on the parent Expectation interface for a high-level introduction to the syntax.

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      ObjectExpectation<T> andCallOriginal()
      When a call fulfilling this expectation is received, pass control to the original implementation of the method on the concrete class being mocked.
      ObjectExpectation<T> andVerifyReturn(Object result)
      On a spy object, when a call otherwise fulfilling this expectation is received, delegate to the object being spied upon, then only fulfill this expectation if the value returned matches the given parameter.
      ObjectExpectation<T> andVerifyThrow(Throwable throwable)
      On a spy object, when a call otherwise fulfilling this expectation is received, delegate to the object being spied upon, then only fulfill this expectation if an exception is thrown matching the given parameter.

      The method that this expectation should match follows this call.

      • Methods inherited from interface moxie.Cardinality

    • Method Detail

      • willReturnVerified

        ObjectExpectation<T> willReturnVerified(Object result)
        On a spy object, when a call otherwise fulfilling this expectation is received, delegate to the object being spied upon, then only fulfill this expectation if the value returned matches the given parameter.

        Note that you can use the matcher methods to match on the return value.

        This method only makes sense for spy objects or PARTIAL mocks; calling this method on an expectation being set on a mock object raises an error.

        Note that willReturnVerified() and andVerifyReturn() do exactly the same thing - use whichever method results in the syntax you prefer best.

        Parameters:
        result - a value or matcher invocation to be compared with the value returned by the underlying method
        Returns:
        this object, for call chaining

      • andVerifyReturn

        ObjectExpectation<T> andVerifyReturn(Object result)
        On a spy object, when a call otherwise fulfilling this expectation is received, delegate to the object being spied upon, then only fulfill this expectation if the value returned matches the given parameter.

        Note that you can use the matcher methods to match on the return value.

        This method only makes sense for spy objects or PARTIAL mocks; calling this method on an expectation being set on a mock object raises an error.

        Note that willReturnVerified() and andVerifyReturn() do exactly the same thing - use whichever method results in the syntax you prefer best.

        Parameters:
        result - a value or matcher invocation to be compared with the value returned by the underlying method
        Returns:
        this object, for call chaining

      • willThrowVerified

        ObjectExpectation<T> willThrowVerified(Throwable throwable)
        On a spy object, when a call otherwise fulfilling this expectation is received, delegate to the object being spied upon, then only fulfill this expectation if an exception is thrown matching the given parameter.

        Note that you can use the matcher methods to match on the exception object.

        This method only makes sense for spy objects; calling this method on an expectation being set on a mock object raises an error.

        Note that willThrowVerified() and andVerifyThrow() do exactly the same thing - use whichever method results in the syntax you prefer best.

        Parameters:
        throwable - a Throwable or matcher invocation to be compared with the exception thrown by the underlying method
        Returns:
        this object, for call chaining

      • andVerifyThrow

        ObjectExpectation<T> andVerifyThrow(Throwable throwable)
        On a spy object, when a call otherwise fulfilling this expectation is received, delegate to the object being spied upon, then only fulfill this expectation if an exception is thrown matching the given parameter.

        Note that you can use the matcher methods to match on the exception object.

        This method only makes sense for spy objects; calling this method on an expectation being set on a mock object raises an error.

        Note that willThrowVerified() and andVerifyThrow() do exactly the same thing - use whichever method results in the syntax you prefer best.

        Parameters:
        throwable - a Throwable or matcher invocation to be compared with the exception thrown by the underlying method
        Returns:
        this object, for call chaining

      • willCallOriginal

        ObjectExpectation<T> willCallOriginal()
        When a call fulfilling this expectation is received, pass control to the original implementation of the method on the concrete class being mocked.

        This option only makes sense for mocks of concrete classes; specifying it for an interface mock or a spy will raise an MoxieSyntaxError.

        Note that willCallOriginal() and andCallOriginal() do exactly the same thing - use whichever method results in the syntax you prefer best.

        Returns:
        this object, for call chaining

      • andCallOriginal

        ObjectExpectation<T> andCallOriginal()
        When a call fulfilling this expectation is received, pass control to the original implementation of the method on the concrete class being mocked.

        This option only makes sense for mocks of concrete classes; specifying it for an interface mock or a spy will raise an MoxieSyntaxError.

        Note that willCallOriginal() and andCallOriginal() do exactly the same thing - use whichever method results in the syntax you prefer best.

        Returns:
        this object, for call chaining

      • on

        T on()
        The method that this expectation should match follows this call.

        Note that on(), when() and will() do exactly the same thing - use whichever method results in the syntax you prefer best.

        Returns:
        a magic proxy object, on which you should call the method to be expected

      • when

        T when()
        The method that this expectation should match follows this call.

        Note that on(), when() and will() do exactly the same thing - use whichever method results in the syntax you prefer best.

        Returns:
        a magic proxy object, on which you should call the method to be expected

      • will

        T will()
        The method that this expectation should match follows this call.

        Note that on(), when() and will() do exactly the same thing - use whichever method results in the syntax you prefer best.

        Returns:
        a magic proxy object, on which you should call the method to be expected

      • on

        void on(String methodName,
        Object... params)
        Reflectively specify the method on which this expectation is to be set.

        Use this method to set expectations on protected or package-private methods which cannot be specified using the no-parameters version of this method because they are inaccessible from your test class.

        Note that on(), when() and will() do exactly the same thing - use whichever method results in the syntax you prefer best.

        Parameters:
        methodName - The name of the method on which to set the expectation
        params - Values or MoxieMatchers invocations matching the expected parameters

      • when

        void when(String methodName,
          Object... params)
        Reflectively specify the method on which this expectation is to be set.

        Use this method to set expectations on protected or package-private methods which cannot be specified using the no-parameters version of this method because they are inaccessible from your test class.

        Note that on(), when() and will() do exactly the same thing - use whichever method results in the syntax you prefer best.

        Parameters:
        methodName - The name of the method on which to set the expectation
        params - Values or MoxieMatchers invocations matching the expected parameters

        void on(String methodName,
        Class[] paramSignature,
        Object... params)
        Reflectively specify the method on which this expectation is to be set.

        Use this method to set expectations on protected or package-private methods which cannot be specified using the no-parameters version of this method because they are inaccessible from your test class.

        Note that on(), when() and will() do exactly the same thing - use whichever method results in the syntax you prefer best.

        Parameters:
        methodName - The name of the method on which to set the expectation
        paramSignature - Array of Class objects forming the method's parameter signature
        params - Values or MoxieMatchers invocations matching the expected parameters
